title: Dune Groundcherry (Physalis walteri)
text:
Natural history notes
The dune groundcherry (Physalis walteri) is a native plant found in the southeastern United States. A member of the nightshade (Solanaceae) family, this plant produces a fruit that, when ripe, is said to be edible, but it can be toxic if eaten before that. It likes drier conditions with sandy or rocky soils. This plant was named after Thomas Walter, the first botanist in North America to publish a book on plants using the two-part scientific naming system.

title: Elliott’s Milkpea (Galactia elliottii)
text:
Natural history notes
Elliott’s Milkpea (Galactia elliottii) is a trailing legume native to the sandy pinelands and scrub habitats of the southeastern United States. It produces clusters of small pink to purplish flowers that attract bees and butterflies throughout the summer. Like other legumes, it enriches the soil by fixing atmospheric nitrogen through its root nodules. Its twining stems and dense foliage also provide cover for small animals and insects in open, fire-maintained ecosystems.

title: Buttonbush (Cephalanthus occidentalis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Buttonbush (Cephalanthus occidentalis) is a wetland shrub native to much of North America, thriving along pond edges, marshes, and swamps. It is easily recognized by its spherical clusters of fragrant white flowers, which attract bees, butterflies, and hummingbirds. Its seeds are eaten by ducks and other waterfowl, making it valuable for wetland wildlife. Because it tolerates flooding, it also helps stabilize shorelines and improve water quality.

text:
Natural history notes
Northern bluethread (Burmannia biflora) is found across much of Florida, though it has not been documented in every county. Endemic to the southeastern United States, it inhabits pinelands, savannas, bogs, and coastal plains. This species flowers from July through March, producing small, iridescent purple blooms.

title: Red-headed Woodpecker (Melanerpes erythrocephalus)
text:
Natural history notes
The red-headed woodpecker (Melanerpes erythrocephalus) primarily inhabits open woodlands and feeds on a wide variety of food, including insects, fruits, and seeds. Unlike most other woodpecker species, it is particularly skilled at catching insects in flight. Adults are strikingly patterned, with a vivid red head and a contrasting black-and-white body. In Florida, the species is uncommon and has a patchy breeding distribution.

title: Maryland meadowbeauty (Rhexia mariana)
text:
Natural history notes
The Maryland Meadowbeauty (Rhexia mariana) is a showy wildflower native to moist meadows, bogs, and pond edges across the eastern United States. It produces bright pink to lavender, four-petaled flowers with striking yellow stamens that bloom through the summer. The plant thrives in sandy, acidic soils and adds vibrant color to wetland landscapes. Its flowers attract bees and other pollinators, making it an important part of late-season wetland communities.

title: Pine-barren Goldenrod (Solidago fistulosa)
text:
Natural history notes
The Pine-barren Goldenrod (Solidago fistulosa) is a tall, showy wildflower native to the wetlands and pine flatwoods of the southeastern United States. In late summer and fall, it produces dense clusters of bright yellow flowers that attract bees, butterflies, and other pollinators. Unlike many upland goldenrods, it thrives in moist, sandy soils and along pond margins. As a late-season nectar source, it plays an essential role in supporting pollinators before winter.

title: Manyflower Marshpennywort (Hydrocotyle umbellata)
text:
Natural history notes
The Manyflower Marshpennywort (Hydrocotyle umbellata) is a creeping aquatic or semi-aquatic plant found in marshes, ponds, and wet meadows across the southeastern United States. Its round, umbrella-like leaves grow on long stalks, floating on or just above the water’s surface. Clusters of tiny white flowers form in rounded umbels, giving the species its name. By spreading across wet soils, it helps prevent erosion and provides shelter for small aquatic animals.

title: Southern Coastal Violet (Viola septemloba)
text:
Natural history notes
The Southern Coastal Violet (Viola septemloba) is a low-growing wildflower native to sandy soils and open woodlands of the southeastern United States. It is easily recognized by its deep purple, five-petaled flowers and distinctive, lobed leaves. Blooming in early spring, it provides an important nectar source for bees and other pollinators. Like many violets, its leaves also serve as host plants for fritillary butterfly caterpillars.

title: Cuban Bulrush (Cyperus blepharoleptos)
text:
Natural history notes
Cuban bulrush (Cyperus blepharoleptos) is an invasive sedge found throughout Florida and parts of the southeastern United States. Native to Central and South America, this species forms floating mats that can dominate an area, outcompeting other native species. As a result, this plant is often managed for to prevent it from taking over large areas and reducing local biodiversity. This plant is now found in over half of Florida’s waterbodies.

text:
Natural history notes
The Chipping Sparrow (Spizella passerina) is a small songbird with a broad range that includes parts of Alaska, Canada, nearly all of the lower 48 states, Mexico, and the Caribbean. It inhabits forests and primarily feeds on seeds. In Florida, the Chipping Sparrow is a winter visitor. Adults are easily recognized by their distinctive rufous cap.

title: Florida Sensitive Briar (Mimosa floridana)
text:
Natural history notes
The Florida Sensitive Briar (Mimosa floridana) is a sprawling, thorny legume native to the sandy pinelands and scrub habitats of Florida and the southeastern United States. It produces round, pink, puffball-like flowers that attract bees and butterflies in spring and summer. True to its name, its fernlike leaves fold inward when touched—a fascinating defense against herbivores and excessive sunlight. As a nitrogen-fixer, it also enriches the poor, sandy soils where it grows.

title: American Alligator (Alligator mississippiensis)
text:
Natural history notes
The American Alligator (Alligator mississippiensis) is a keystone predator of the southeastern United States, thriving in swamps, marshes, rivers, and lakes. They are opportunistic feeders, eating everything from fish and turtles to birds and mammals, and their famous “gator holes” provide vital wetland refuges for countless other species. Females build large vegetation nests and guard their eggs fiercely, with nest temperature determining the sex of the hatchlings. Once nearly hunted to extinction for their hides, the species rebounded after legal protections and is now celebrated as a major conservation success story.

title: Bottlebrush Threeawn (Aristida spiciformis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Bottlebrush Threeawn (Aristida spiciformis) is a native grass of the southeastern United States, typically growing in dry, sandy soils and open pine habitats. It gets its name from its distinctive seed heads, which resemble tiny bottlebrushes with their long, bristly awns. This hardy grass helps stabilize soil and provides cover for insects and small wildlife. Adapted to fire-maintained ecosystems, it flourishes in the open conditions created by periodic burns.

Natural history notes
The Florida false sunflower is a native flower in the Asteraceae family, which also includes daisies and sunflowers. Endemic to Florida, these plants are typically only found in central and northern parts of the state. The flowers are anywhere from pale green to yellow, almost resembling a tiny starfruit in color and shape, and it has wide, dark green leaves at the base.

title: Yellow Colicroot (Aletris lutea)
text:
Natural history notes
The Yellow Colicroot (Aletris lutea) is a perennial wildflower native to the sandy pinelands and savannas of the southeastern United States. It produces a tall spike of small, yellow, tubular flowers that bloom in late spring and summer. The plant is adapted to dry, fire-prone habitats and is often found alongside other specialist wildflowers. Historically, its bitter roots were used in folk medicine, giving rise to the name “colicroot.”

However, coloration can vary. Margined Leatherwing Beetles get their name from their “leather-like” wings as they are soft rather than hard. Adults often feed on pollen and nectar. While both the adult and larval stages are known to be predatory.

title: Water Spangles (Salvinia minima)
text:
Natural history notes
Water Spangles (Salvinia minima) is a small, free-floating aquatic fern native to Central and South America but widely introduced in the southeastern United States. It forms dense mats of overlapping, oval leaves covered in tiny water-repelling hairs, giving them a velvety appearance. These mats provide shelter for aquatic invertebrates and small fish but can also block sunlight and reduce oxygen levels when they spread excessively. Because of its rapid growth, it is considered invasive in many regions.

title: Shortspike Bluestem (Anatherum brachystachyum)
text:
Natural history notes
The Shortspike Bluestem (Anatherum brachystachyum) is a native perennial grass that grows in dry, sandy soils and open woodlands of the southeastern United States. It forms clumps that provide shelter for insects and small animals while also helping stabilize fragile soils. Its seeds are an important seasonal food source for birds and other wildlife. As part of the bluestem group, it contributes to the structure and resilience of fire-maintained ecosystems.

Mexican prickly poppy (Argenome mexicana) is a native plant in the poppy (Papaveraceae) family. Often, this plant is confused with a thistle because of its prickly leaves but can be easily distinguished from thistles based on its yellow flowers, if present, or its latex-like sap. While this is a native plant, it is considered a weed and is typically managed for by herbicides. It is also toxic to livestock!

title: Cinnabar Bracket (Trametes sanguinea)
text:
Natural history notes
The Cinnabar Bracket (Trametes sanguinea) is a striking wood-decay fungus recognized by its bright red, velvety upper surface and pale pore underside. It grows on dead hardwood, helping decompose tough lignin and cellulose and recycling nutrients back into the forest ecosystem. Like other bracket fungi, it forms thin, shelf-like fruiting bodies that persist for months. Its vivid coloration makes it a standout among woodland fungi, even though it is inedible.

text:
Natural history notes
The Jester Lichen (Cladonia leporina) is a colorful, branching lichen commonly found on sandy soils, rotting wood, and open pine forests of the southeastern United States. It forms bright orange to red fruiting tips that stand out against its pale stalks, giving it a whimsical, “jester-like” appearance. Like other lichens, it is a symbiosis between a fungus and algae, allowing it to thrive in nutrient-poor habitats. It contributes to soil formation, moisture retention, and provides microhabitats for small invertebrates.

title: Pine Warbler (Setophaga pinus)
text:
Natural history notes
The Pine Warbler (Setophaga pinus) is a small songbird of the eastern United States, closely tied to pine forests where it nests and forages. Unlike many warblers, it eats a varied diet of insects, seeds, and berries, often visiting backyard feeders in winter. Its clear, musical trill is one of the first bird songs heard in spring, sometimes continuing year-round in warmer regions. This species is considered an important indicator of healthy pine ecosystems.

title: Swollen Bladderwort (Utricularia inflata)
text:
Natural history notes
The Swollen Bladderwort (Utricularia inflata) was first described by Thomas Walter in 1788. Although it is native in many U.S. states, it is also known to be introduced (and potentially invasive) in regions beyond its native range (e.g. New York, Massachusetts, Washington), where it can form dense mats that suppress native aquatic plants, alter sediment chemistry, and reduce habitat quality. Because its traps operate on a suction mechanism (the plant pumps water out of the bladder to create negative pressure, then when a prey touches trigger hairs, the door “buckles” open and sucks in water and the prey), it is part of the fascinating mechanical world of bladderwort trapping.

title: Swollen Bladderwort (Utricularia inflata)

text:
Natural history notes
The Spurge Nettle (Cnidoscolus stimulosus) is a native wildflower of the southeastern United States, commonly found in dry, sandy soils and open pinelands. Despite its attractive white, five-petaled flowers, the plant is covered in stinging hairs that can cause a painful rash on contact. It produces small, spiny fruits and serves as a host plant for several butterfly species, including the gray hairstreak. Its striking mix of beauty and defense makes it a memorable component of sandy upland habitats.

title: Natal Grass (Melinis repens)
text:
Natural history notes
The Natal Grass (Melinis repens) is a perennial (often short-lived) tufted grass in the family Poaceae, native to southern Africa but widely naturalized across warm regions including Florida, the Caribbean, and the southern U.S. It is easily recognized by its silky, reddish-pink flower clusters (panicles), which mature to a silvery white as the seeds ripen, giving fields a shimmering appearance in sunlight. Its name Natal grass comes from the Natal region of South Africa, its place of origin. In Florida, it is listed as invasive species.

The Seaside Primrose-Willow (Ludwigia maritima) is a perennial herb native to the coastal plain of the southeastern United States. The Gopher Apple (Geobalanus oblongifolius) is a low, spreading shrub native to the sandy soils of the southeastern United States. title: Laurel Dodder (Cassytha filiformis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Laurel Dodder (Cassytha filiformis) is a twining, parasitic vine widely distributed in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide, including Florida. It produces long, threadlike, leafless green stems that twine around host plants, attaching with haustoria that penetrate the host’s tissue to extract water and nutrients. In the Caribbean, it is commonly called “love vine”, tied to traditional folklore and used in folk medicine. Its presence in coastal ecosystems contributes to structural complexity, providing cover for insects and small animals, though it can also be a pest in orchards or disturbed landscapes.

title: Pondcypress (Taxodium ascendens)
text:
Natural history notes
The Pondcypress (Taxodium ascendens) is classified as a perennial gymnosperm that is native to the southeastern United States. It reaches on average 15–18 metres (49–59 ft) in height. It is typically used for ornamental purposes or decoration in more urban environments unlike the bald cypress which can be used in heavy duty construction. Pond cypress are also used in wetland restoration and enhancement. It is susceptible to fires during the drier arid seasons where ponds lose the majority of their water but these trees have developed a thicker bark to better survive these conditions. ## References / links

title: Western Honey Bee (Apis mellifera)
text:
Natural history notes
The Western Honey Bee (Apis mellifera) is one of the world’s most widespread and important pollinators, originally native to Europe, Africa, and western Asia but now introduced globally. Living in highly organized colonies, they build wax combs to store honey and rear brood, with each hive containing a queen, workers, and drones. They play a critical ecological and agricultural role by pollinating a wide variety of plants, including many food crops. Though resilient and adaptable, honey bees face pressures from habitat loss, pesticides, diseases, and parasites such as the Varroa mite.

title: American Flagfish (Jordanella floridae)
text:
Natural history notes
American Flagfish (Jordanella floridae) is a small, native fish found in Florida, though it has been found as a nonnative in a few small areas in the southeast. A colorful, iridescent fish, flagfish are common in the aquarium trade, and its nonnative introductions are likely the result of its popularity there. A type of killifish, these fish like shallow, warm water and can be found near aquatic plants. These fish earned the name “flagfish” because males have a red and white striped pattern, resembling the American flag.

title: American Flagfish (Jordanella floridae)

Natural history notes
Orange Milkwort (Senega lutea) is an herbaceous plant with yellow-orange flowers that bloom between April and October. Affectionately known as a Swamp Cheeto, you can see the bright flowers in damp sandy soils, typically adjacent to a wetland in the summer months in Florida. Orange Milkwort flowers are self-pollinating, but are spread by ants who consume fleshy elaisomes around the seed, but leave the seed itself in tact to germinate.

title: Sweetbay Magnolia (Magnolia virginiana)
text:
Natural history notes
The Sweetbay Magnolia (Magnolia virginiana) is a semi-evergreen to evergreen tree native to the southeastern United States, often found in swamps, wet woods, and along streams. It typically grows 10–20 m tall, with smooth gray bark and glossy, lanceolate leaves that are dark green above and silvery-white beneath. It is sometimes called “beaver tree” because trappers used its twigs as bait for beaver traps, taking advantage of the species’ sweet fragrance. It is widely planted in landscapes for its fragrance, attractive foliage, and tolerance of wet soils.

Natural history notes
The Little Metalmark (Calephelis virginiensis) is one of the smallest butterflies in North America, recognized by the tiny metallic silver spots that shimmer on its orange-brown wings. It inhabits open sandy areas, pine flatwoods, and coastal plains of the southeastern United States. Adults feed on nectar from asters and other small wildflowers, while caterpillars specialize on plants in the aster family. Though inconspicuous in flight, its glittering wing spots give it a jewel-like appearance when seen up close.

Leavenworth’s Tickseed (Coreopsis leavenworthii) is a cheerful wildflower native to the wetlands and flatwoods of the southeastern United States, particularly Florida. It produces bright yellow, daisy-like blooms with notched petals that appear nearly year-round in warm climates. The flowers attract bees, butterflies, and other pollinators, making it a favorite in native plant gardens. Its adaptability to both wet and dry soils allows it to thrive in a wide range of habitats.

text:
Natural history notes
The Knotted Spikerush (Eleocharis interstincta) is a robust perennial sedge native to the southeastern U.S. It typically grows in marshes, ditches, swamps, and shallow wetlands, forming dense clumps up to 1.5 m tall. The stems are cylindrical, hollow, and jointed, with distinct swollen “nodes” (interstices), giving rise to its common name. Dense stands help stabilize soils in wetlands and provide cover for fish, amphibians, and invertebrates.

The Common Axil-Flower (Mecardonia acuminata) is a small, creeping wildflower native to moist sandy soils, ditches, and open wetlands across the southeastern United States. Shiny Blueberry (Vaccinium myrsinites) is an evergreen shrub that thrives in dry, sandy soils in scrub, prairie, and flatwood habitats. Tracy’s Silkgrass (Pityopsis tracyi) is a perennial wildflower native to the sandy soils and pine flatwoods of the southeastern United States. It produces bright yellow, daisy-like flowers in late summer and fall that provide nectar for bees and butterflies. Its narrow, silvery leaves are covered in fine hairs that give the plant a silky sheen and help it conserve moisture. Like other silkgrasses, it is well adapted to fire-prone habitats, contributing to the resilience of longleaf pine ecosystems.

title: Hairy Indigo (Indigofera hirsuta)
text:
Natural history notes
The Hairy Indigo (Indigofera hirsuta) is a hairy herb or small subshrub in the legume family (Fabaceae) that can grow erect to about 1 m tall, often from a deep central root or rhizome. It is native to the Old World tropics (Africa, Asia, Australia) but now is naturalized or introduced in many tropical and subtropical regions globally, including parts of the southeastern U.S. It exhibits a floral-tripping or “explosive” pollination mechanism typical of many Indigofera species: if a pollinator touches the base of the banner petal, the petals can collapse and cause rapid release (“puff”) of pollen from the anthers. In some contexts I. hirsuta is considered a weed or invasive — in Florida for example it is non-native and shows up in disturbed areas.

title: Hairy Indigo (Indigofera hirsuta)

title: Alligatorweed (Alternanthera philoxeroides)
text:
Natural history notes
Alligatorweed (Alternanthera philoxeroides) is an invasive plant that first arrived in Florida over 100 years ago. Originally from South America, it has spread widely across the state and often takes over shorelines, where it harms native habitats. In the 1960s and 1970s, scientists brought in three insects from its native range—a flea beetle, a thrips, and a stem borer—to help keep it under control. These insects have done a good job of reducing alligatorweed in many places, and managers can still use them when needed. But even with these efforts, the plant has never been completely removed from Florida and remains a problem today.

title: Ornate Bella Moth (Utetheisa ornatrix)
text:
Natural history notes
The Ornate Bella Moth (Utetheisa ornata) is a small moth known for its yellow front wings with white bands and black dots, and bright pink hindwings. The larvae are orange-brown with broad black bands on each segment with white spots. Unlike most moths, the Ornate Bella Moth is diurnal. Plant species from the genus Crotalaria serve as the main host plant for these moths. Due to the presence of pyrrolizidine alkaloids in Crotalaria plants, Ornate Bella Moths in all stages become poisonous to predators.

title: Polyphemus Moth (Antheraea polyphemus)
text:
Natural history notes
The Polyphemus moth (Antheraea polyphemus) is a large silk moth found across North America, ranging from Canada to Mexico. It ranks among Florida’s largest moth species. Each wing has a distinctive eyespot pattern, which the moth can flash open to startle predators. The species is named after Polyphemus, the one-eyed cyclops from Greek mythology, in reference to these prominent spots.

title: Osprey (Pandion haliaetus)
text:
Natural history notes
The osprey (Pandion haliaetus) is a native raptor found in every state in the United States. These birds primarily eat fish, and they are excellent fishermen. They catch one out of every four fish they hunt! When they catch a fish, they will orient the head straight, into the wind, as they fly away from the water so that it is more aerodynamic. Ospreys are generally migratory, but in Florida (and other parts of the southeast), these raptors mostly stay year-round, with a few exceptions in the southern parts of the state.

title: Eastern Milk-Pea (Galactia regularis)
text:
Natural history notes
The eastern milkpea (Galactia regularis) is a native legume found in the southeastern United States. This vine typically has a purple flower associated with it and can be found climbing along the ground or even on other plants! This species, like other legumes, fixes nitrogen from the atmosphere into the soil through a symbiotic relationship with bacteria in the soil. As a result, this plant creates a more fertile soil.

Natural history notes
The Smallfruit Beggarticks (Bidens mitis) is a native wildflower of wetlands, marsh edges, and ditches throughout the southeastern United States. It produces bright yellow, daisy-like flowers that bloom from late summer into fall, providing nectar for bees, butterflies, and other pollinators. Its small, barbed seeds easily cling to fur and clothing, helping the plant disperse widely. By thriving in wet soils, it supports pollinator activity and stabilizes shoreline habitats.

The Musky Mint (Hyptis alata) is a fragrant, mint-family wildflower native to wetlands, marsh edges, and moist meadows of the southeastern United States. Saw greenbrier is a rampant vine from thickened and knotty rhizome with stems and branches are four-ridge. Native Americans historically used parts of this plant: its large rhizome was cooked or ground for food, and roots were sometimes used medicinally. The Acadian French name for all the members of the genus Smilax is “cantaque”. This name comes from the Choctaw name for greenbriar (Holmes 1990).

Natural history notes
The Dwarf Huckleberry (Gaylussacia dumosa) is a low, deciduous shrub native to the sandy pine forests and scrublands of the southeastern United States. In spring, it produces clusters of small, bell-shaped white or pink flowers that attract bees. By summer, these give way to dark blue berries that are eaten by birds, mammals, and people alike. Its dense, shrubby growth helps stabilize soils and contributes to the rich understory diversity of fire-adapted ecosystems.

title: Marsh Pink (Sabatia stellaris)
text:
Natural history notes
The Marsh Pink (Sabatia stellaris) is an annual wildflower native to coastal salt marshes and brackish shores of the eastern United States, from New England to Florida. It thrives in moist, sandy, or muddy soils influenced by tides, often forming showy colonies in open marshes. Unlike many wildflowers, it is strongly tied to coastal salt marshes, making it an indicator of healthy tidal wetland ecosystems. It is short-lived: each plant completes its life cycle in one season, relying on abundant seed production. The fruit is a dry capsule containing up to 600 seeds.

title: Running Oak (Quercus pumila)
text:
Natural history notes
The Running Oak (Quercus pumila) is a low, spreading oak native to the southeastern United States. Unlike most oaks, it grows as a prostrate or low, shrubby plant (usually under 1 m tall) that spreads by underground rhizomes, forming colonies. Acorns are small, borne singly or in pairs, and serve as food for wildlife including birds and small mammals. It is well adapted to drought, nutrient-poor sandy soils, and fire-maintained ecosystems.

title: Evans’ Deer Moss (Cladonia evansii)
text:
Natural history notes
Evans’ Deer Moss (Cladonia evansii) is a pale, branching lichen that covers sandy soils and pine flatwoods in the southeastern United States. Despite its name, it is not a true moss but a lichen, formed from a partnership between fungus and algae. It plays an important ecological role by helping retain moisture, prevent soil erosion, and provide forage for deer and other wildlife. Its delicate, gray-green mats are also a distinctive feature of healthy, undisturbed pine ecosystems.

The Blue-gray Gnatcatcher (Polioptila caerulea) is a tiny, restless songbird of woodlands and thickets across much of North America. It flits constantly through foliage, wagging its long tail as it snaps up insects and spiders. Its high, thin calls and buzzy song are often heard before the bird is seen. During breeding season, pairs build delicate, lichen-covered nests that resemble small knots on tree branches.

title: American Pokeweed (Phytolacca americana)
text:
Natural history notes
The American Pokeweed (Phytolacca americana) is widely dispersed by birds and quickly colonizes exposed mineral soil even in undisturbed forests, such as on tree-fall tip-up mounds or flood scours. It is most abundant, however, as a weed of urban, suburban, and agricultural disturbances. Be carefule! Its berries and mature stems are poisonous; the young stems have been used as a potherb and the purple berries as a source of ink. Although all parts of the Pokeweed are poisonous to humans, some folks take the risk of eating poke salad each spring.

Natural history notes
The green treefrog (Hyla cinerea) is a bright green species found throughout Florida. It closely resembles the squirrel treefrog (Hyla squirella), which is also common in the state, but can usually be distinguished by a white stripe along its side, often bordered in black. In some individuals this stripe may be absent, in which case size and coloration help with identification. Green treefrogs primarily feed on insects and are typically found near water, including marshes, swamps, ponds, and lakes.

text:
Natural history notes
The horned passalid (Odontotaenius disjunctus) is a native beetle found throughout the southeastern, northeastern, and midwestern parts of the United States. In Florida, their range stops in the central part of the state. These shiny black beetles can be identified by their tiny horn on the very top of their head, between their eyes. These beetles can be large (over 3cm in length), and adults have large mandible mouthparts. While they have wings, this animal rarely uses them, preferring to walk instead of fly when travelling long distances.

title: Small Swollen Bladderwort (Utricularia radiata)
text:
Natural history notes
The Small Swollen Bladderwort (Utricularia radiata) is a small, free-floating aquatic carnivorous plant native to eastern North America. The name radiata means “rayed” or “radiating,” referring to the whorl of inflated float structures. It was once considered a variety of Utricularia inflata (U. inflata var. minor) before being recognized as a distinct species. Although the inflated spokes look like flotation organs, their main role is to stabilize and elevate the inflorescence, while the plant relies on its internal buoyancy for floating.

title: Creeping Beggarweed (Desmodium incanum)
text:
Natural history notes
The Creeping Beggarweed (Desmodium incanum) is a perennial (or subshrubby) legume in the family Fabaceae, spreading via both stolons/runners and seed. Because it is a nitrogen-fixing legume, the Creeping Beggarweed can improve soil fertility (adding nitrogen to soils via root symbiosis with rhizobia), which is why it was once promoted as a forage or cover plant in tropical and subtropical regions. Though useful in some systems, it is considered a weed in many places (including Florida), partly because of its aggressive vegetative spread and capacity to colonize lawns, gardens, and turf.

title: Golden Topminnow (Fundulus chrysotus)
text:
Natural history notes
Golden topminnow (Fundulus chrysotus) is a small, native fish found in freshwater systems throughout the southeastern United States. This species loves warm, shallow water and is often found near aquatic plants, where it can hide from predators like bass and sunfish. This species is sexually dimorphic, meaning that males and females look different; while both have a vibrant yellow body, the males will often have red scales on the body and caudal fin, while the females will have white scales. Given its bright colors, this minnow is also a popular aquarium fish!

The Savannah False Pimpernel (Lindernia grandiflora) is a creeping wetland plant native to the southeastern United States, often found along pond margins, ditches, and wet meadows. It produces small, violet to blue, two-lipped flowers that bloom through much of the growing season. Its spreading stems root easily at the nodes, forming mats that help stabilize muddy soils. This delicate species adds color to shallow wetlands while providing nectar for small pollinators.

title: Savannah False Pimpernel (Lindernia grandiflora)

title: Southern Dewberry (Rubus trivialis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Southern Dewberry (Rubus trivialis) is a trailing bramble native to the southeastern United States, commonly found along roadsides, woodland edges, and open fields. It produces white, five-petaled flowers in spring, followed by sweet black berries that are eaten by birds, mammals, and people alike. Its thorny, creeping stems provide cover for small animals and help stabilize soil in disturbed areas. As one of the first brambles to fruit each year, it’s an important early food source for wildlife.

title: Dwarf Sundew (Drosera brevifolia)
text:
Natural history notes
The Dwarf Sundew (Drosera brevifolia) is one of the smallest carnivorous plants in North America, typically found in sandy, nutrient-poor soils of the southeastern United States. Its tiny, red, spoon-shaped leaves are covered in sticky hairs that trap and digest insects to supplement its nutrient intake. The plant produces delicate pink flowers that rise just above the leaves in spring. Despite its miniature size, it plays an important role in balancing insect populations in its fragile habitats.

By providing shelter for fish and invertebrates, it plays an important role in healthy wetland ecosystems.

Saw Palmetto (Serona repens) is an evergreen palm named after American botanist Sereno Watson. The petiole, or leaf stem, famously has spiky teeth giving this plant it’s namesake, Saw Palmetto. The Saw Palmetto serves as the host plant for the Monk Skipper and Palmetto Skipper butterflies, and the berries are a food source for over 100 different animals in Florida.

title: Eastern Bluebird (Sialia sialis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Eastern Bluebird (Sialia sialis) is a small thrush found in open fields, meadows, and forest edges across eastern North America. Known for their brilliant blue plumage and reddish breast, they primarily feed on insects and berries, often hunting from low perches. They nest in tree cavities or nest boxes, which has made them a favorite among bird enthusiasts and conservation groups. Once in decline due to habitat loss and competition from invasive species like starlings, Eastern Bluebird populations have rebounded thanks to widespread nest box programs.

title: Palmetto Skipper (Euphyes arpa)
text:
Natural history notes
The Palmetto Skipper (Euphyes arpa) is a stout, dark brown butterfly found in the coastal plains and pine flatwoods of the southeastern United States. It is closely associated with saw palmetto (Serenoa repens), whose leaves serve as the sole food source for its caterpillars. Adults fly low and fast, feeding on nectar from a variety of flowers, especially in sunny openings. Because of its reliance on palmetto-dominated habitats, it benefits from the maintenance of healthy, fire-managed ecosystems.

text:
Natural history notes
The Narrow-leaved Blue-eyed Grass (Sisyrinchium angustifolium) is a delicate perennial in the iris family, native to meadows, open woods, and moist prairies across eastern North America. Despite its name, it isn’t a true grass—its slender leaves simply resemble one. In spring, it produces small, star-shaped blue to violet flowers with bright yellow centers that attract bees and other pollinators. This charming wildflower adds subtle color and ecological value to grassy habitats.

title: Purple Bladderwort (Utricularia purpurea)
text:
Natural history notes
The Purple Bladderwort (Utricularia purpurea) is a submersed aquatic plant. The epithet purpurea means “purple,” referencing the distinctive purple or lavender coloration of its flowers. In some northern parts of its range (e.g. Wisconsin), it has sometimes grown into dense surface mats that impair recreation (tangled boats, etc.), especially in years when populations “boom”. In such dense masses, many plants may not flower; flowering seems tied to conditions that let the floral stalk maintain elevation above water (sometimes aided by surrounding vegetation like water lilies).

title: Climbing Dayflower (Commelina diffusa)
text:
Natural history notes
Climbing Dayflower (Commelina diffusa) is a creeping, mat-forming annual or short-lived perennial herb. It produces distinctive blue flowers with two large upper petals and one small, inconspicuous lower petal, usually opening in the morning and fading by afternoon. Its mucilaginous stems and leaves have been used in folk medicine in Asia and the Pacific for fevers, sore throats, and skin ailments. In some regions it is used as a fodder plant for livestock, though in others it is considered a noxious weed.

title: Sessile Marshweed (Limnophila sessiliflora)
text:
Natural history notes
Sessile Marshweed (Limnophila sessiliflora) is an aquatic plant native to Asia but now naturalized in parts of the southeastern United States. It has finely divided, feathery underwater leaves and whorls of broader leaves at the water’s surface, making it popular in aquariums. In the wild, it grows rapidly in ponds, ditches, and wetlands, where it can form dense mats. While it provides shelter for fish and invertebrates, it may also compete with native aquatic plants when it spreads aggressively.

title: Roughhair Rosette Grass (Dichanthelium strigosum)
text:
Natural history notes
The Roughhair Rosette Grass (Dichanthelium strigosum) has three recognized subspecies (or varieties):var. glabrescens, var. leucoblepharis, and var. strigosum. The three subspecies are mostly sympatric and sometimes grow together, with occasional intergradation. It extends from the southeastern Flora region south into Mexico, the Caribbean, and into northern South America. Its primary panicles are briefly open-pollinated in April or May; the secondary panicles, which are produced from May through November, are cleistogamous.

The Walter’s viburnum (Viburnum obovatum) makes a great addition to the Florida landscape as a small tree or large shrub. Pollinators are attracted to its showy spring flower clusters, while birds and other wildlife feast on its abundant summer and fall fruit production and use its dense foliage for nesting and cover. Some cultivars have been bred to have compact form or other desirable traits, making this species quite versatile in landscaping (hedges, screens, specimen plantings). In more northern parts of its range or during cold winters, V. obovatum may drop leaves briefly (become semi-deciduous) before leafing out again.

Natural history notes
The Roundleaf Bluet (Houstonia procumbens) is a tiny, low-growing wildflower of the southeastern United States, often carpeting sandy soils, lawns, and open woodlands. It produces small white flowers with yellow centers in early spring, sometimes forming dense mats that brighten the ground. Its rounded leaves form tight rosettes close to the soil, helping it tolerate dry, open habitats. Though delicate in appearance, it plays a role in supporting early-season pollinators like bees and flies.

title: Deceptive Bluestem (Anatherum campbellii)
text:
Natural history notes
The Deceptive Bluestem (Anatherum campbellii) is a perennial grass native to the southeastern United States, typically found in dry, sandy habitats and open woodlands. Like other bluestems, it plays an important role in stabilizing soils and providing cover for small animals and insects. Its flowers and seeds support grassland biodiversity, offering food for insects and birds. Though not widely known, it contributes to the resilience of native plant communities in fire-adapted ecosystems. ## References / links

title: Turkey Vulture (Cathartes aura)
text:
Natural history notes
The Turkey Vulture (Cathartes aura) is a widespread scavenger found across Noth and South America, easily recognized by its red, bare head and long, two-toned wings. Unlike most birds, it relies heavily on its keen sense of smell to locate carrion, soaring low to detect the scent of decay. By feeding on dead animals, it plays a vital role in preventing the spread of disease and recycling nutrients back into ecosystems. Its graceful, teetering flight makes it one of the most efficient soaring birds in the world.

text:
Natural history notes
The Pinewoods Fingergrass (Eustachys petraea) is a perennial bunchgrass native to the Caribbean, Central America, South America, and extending into southern Florida. It grows in sandy, coastal, and rocky soils, often in open pinelands, dunes, and disturbed ground. Its dense tufts help reduce soil erosion in dry, sandy landscapes. The epithet petraea means “rocky,” reflecting its tendency to grow in thin, stony or sandy soils.

title: Confused Cloudywing (Cecropterus confusis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Confused Cloudywing (Cecropterus confusis) is a medium-sized skipper butterfly found in open woods, fields, and edges across the southeastern United States. It is often difficult to distinguish from other cloudywing species, which is how it earned its name. Adults feed on nectar from a variety of flowers, while caterpillars develop on legumes such as tick-trefoils and bush-clovers. As both pollinators and prey for birds and other insects, they play a small but important role in local ecosystems.

title: Rabbitbells (Crotalaria rotundifolia)
text:
Natural history notes
Rabbitbells (Crotalaria rotundifolia) is a low, spreading legume native to the sandy soils of the southeastern United States. It produces small, bright yellow, pea-like flowers that bloom through much of the growing season. As a nitrogen-fixer, it enriches poor soils while providing nectar for bees and other pollinators. Its seeds are contained in small pods that rattle when dry, a trait common to the rattlepods in the genus Crotalaria.

title: Carolina Ponysfoot (Dichondra carolinensis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Carolina Ponysfoot (Dichondra carolinensis) is a perennial, mat-forming groundcover native to the southeastern United States and the Caribbean. It grows prostrate, rooting at the nodes, and forms dense carpets of small, kidney- to horseshoe-shaped leaves. Its dense mats can help suppress weeds. Because of its soft leaves and low growth, it is sometimes grown deliberately in gardens as a “living mulch”.

title: Shiny-leaved Wild Coffee (Psychotria nervosa)
text:
Natural history notes
The Shiny-leaved Wild Coffee (Psychotria nervosa) is a Florida native shrub that gets its common name from the small, red, ellipsoid fruit it produces. It typically grows in shady, moist but well-drained habitats such as hammocks, pine flatwoods edges, coastal uplands, and sandy soils, tolerating partial sun in cultivation. Despite its common name “wild coffee,” P. nervosa is not known to contain caffeine, and efforts to brew it as a coffee substitute are reported to yield poor taste and even headaches. One host interaction: the larvae of the moth Metriochroa psychotriella feed on the leaves of P. nervosa, mining them internally.

The Lanceleaf Arrowhead (Sagittaria lancifolia) is a tall aquatic plant native to wetlands, marshes, and ditches of the southeastern United States. It is named for its long, lance-shaped leaves that rise well above the water’s surface. In summer, it produces white, three-petaled flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and flies. Its tubers and seeds provide food for ducks, muskrats, and other wetland wildlife, making it an important species in aquatic ecosystems.

title: Cogon Grass (Imperata cylindrica)
text:
Natural history notes
The Cogon Grass (Imperata cylindrica) has long yellow-green leaves with an obviously off-center midrib and slightly serrated margins. Its height means that cogongrass often stands out from surrounding vegetation, making it easy to spot from a distance. It is a highly flammable pyrophyte, and can spread rapidly by colonizing disturbed areas and encouraging more frequent wildfires. It is regarded as an excellent plant for thatching the roofs of traditional homes throughout south-east Asia, and is even grown as a crop for this purpose. A common expression in the Philippines is ningas kugon (‘cogon brush fire’). It is a figure of speech for quitters, specifically people who show a fervent interest in a new project but lose interest quickly, in reference to the propensity of cogongrass to catch fire and burn out quickly.

title: Cogon Grass (Imperata cylindrica)

title: Lakeshore Nutrush (Scleria lacustris)
text:
Natural history notes
Also called Wright’s nutrush, lakeshore nutrush (Scleria lacustris) is an invasive sedge found mostly in central and south Florida wetlands. This plant is classified by the Florida Invasive Species Council as a Category I invasive exotic, meaning that it has been shown to alter native plant communities. As such, this species is often managed for to prevent it from competing with other native plants. Its seeds can be spread easily via airboats, and saturated conditions can be used to stop their seeds from sprouting.

title: Virginia Pepperweed (Lepidium virginicum)
text:
Natural history notes
Virginia Pepperweed (Lepidium virginicum) is a common annual plant found in fields, roadsides, and disturbed soils throughout much of North America. It produces small white flowers and flat, circular seedpods that resemble tiny coins, earning it the nickname “poor man’s pepper.” Both its leaves and seeds have a sharp, peppery taste and have been used as a seasoning in folk traditions. Its flowers attract small pollinators, while its seeds are eaten by birds and other wildlife.

title: Southern Umbrella-Sedge (Fuirena scirpoidea)
text:
Natural history notes
Sessile Marshweed (Limnophila sessiliflora) is an aquatic plant native to Asia but now naturalized in parts of the southeastern United States. It has finely divided, feathery underwater leaves and whorls of broader leaves at the water’s surface, making it popular in aquariums. In the wild, it grows rapidly in ponds, ditches, and wetlands, where it can form dense mats. While it provides shelter for fish and invertebrates, it may also compete with native aquatic plants when it spreads aggressively.

The Ten-angled Pipewort (Eriocaulon decangulare) is an aquatic or semi-aquatic wildflower found in bogs, wet meadows, and shallow ponds across the southeastern United States. The Fourpetal St. Johnswort (Hypericum tetrapetalum) is a perennial shrub native to the wetlands and pine flatwoods of the southeastern United States. This species thrives in moist, sandy soils and often plays a role in stabilizing wetland edges. Like other St. Johnsworts, it has a long history of traditional medicinal use, though its primary ecological role is providing nectar for pollinators such as bees and butterflies.

The Common Bracken (Pteridium aquilinum) is one of the most widespread ferns in the world, thriving in dry woodlands, fields, and disturbed soils. Its large, triangular fronds can form dense colonies that provide cover for wildlife but can also outcompete other plants. Adapted to fire, it quickly resprouts from underground rhizomes after burns. Though sometimes considered invasive, it plays an important role in stabilizing soils and providing early successional habitat.

title: Pine Woods Tree Frog (Hyla femoralis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Pine Woods Tree Frog (Hyla femoralis) is a small, adaptable tree frog found throughout the southeastern United States, especially in pine forests, flatwoods, and cypress swamps. It is known for its distinctive rapid, chattering call, sometimes nicknamed the “Morse code frog.” By day it hides in tree cavities, under bark, or among vegetation, and at night it forages for insects and other small invertebrates. During the breeding season, it gathers in temporary ponds and wetlands to lay eggs, making it an important indicator of healthy forested wetland ecosystems.

The Grassleaf Barbara’s-Buttons (Marshallia graminifolia) is a perennial wildflower native to the southeastern United States, where it grows in pine flatwoods, savannas, wet meadows, and along pond margins. title: Anhinga (Anhinga anhinga)
text:
Natural history notes
The Anhinga (Anhinga anhinga) is a waterbird found throughout the southeastern United States. It hunts fish by diving and swimming underwater. The species is also known as the “snakebird,” since only its slender neck and beak are visible above the water while swimming, giving it the appearance of a snake. Another common name, “water turkey,” comes from its long tail, which can fan out like that of a turkey.

title: Sand Cordgrass (Sporobolus bakeri)
text:
Natural history notes
Sand cordgrass (Sporobolus bakeri), also called marsh grass, is a native grass found in the southeastern United States. This is a tall grass, typically 3-6 feet tall, and is typically found in clumps. While this grass is typically found in wetlands, it can live in upland areas, too, making it robust to a variety of different landscapes throughout Florida. Its appearance and tolerance for a variety of environmental conditions also makes it a popular ornamental plant! This plant was also recently reclassified from Spartina bakeri to Sporobolus bakeri, so it may still appear as Spartina bakeri in some sources.

title: Sand Cordgrass (Sporobolus bakeri)

title: Bald Eagle (Haliaeetus leucocephalus)
text:
Natural history notes
The Bald Eagle (Haliaeetus leucocephalus), the national bird of the United States, once faced near extinction. Thanks to extensive conservation efforts, their populations have rebounded, and in 2007 the species was formally removed from the endangered species list. Today, Florida hosts one of the densest concentrations of bald eagle nests in the lower 48 states. Bald eagles have a broad range, occurring throughout most of Alaska and the contiguous United States. Their diet consists primarily of fish. While they are capable hunters, they often take advantage of other birds of prey, such as ospreys, or fishing mammals to steal fish.

title: Simmonds’ Aster (Symphyotrichum simmondsii)
text:
Natural history notes
The Simmonds’ Aster (Symphyotrichum simmondsii) is a perennial plant native to the Southeastern Coastal Plain of the U.S and most prevalent throughout peninsular Florida. Occupying various habitats from moist to dry, it forms colonies via long underground rhizomes and typically blooms from October through January. The species was first described as Aster simmondsii Small. The genus name Symphyotrichum is from the Greek sýmphysis, meaning “growing together”.

title: Oriental False Hawksbeard (Youngia japonica)
text:
Natural history notes
The Oriental False Hawksbeard (Youngia japonica) is an annual that produces yellow flowers. It typically grows in disturbed sites, lawns, gardens, roadsides, and cracks in pavement, forming basal rosettes of lobed leaves before sending up slender flowering stems up to 30–60 cm tall. Its epithet japonica means “of Japan,” where the species was first described scientifically. This species has spread rapidly in southeastern region, and is now moving into minimally-disturbed natural areas.

However, the introduction of Dutch elm disease has caused major declines in this species, placing it on the endangered species list. The American elm can be incorporated into native plant gardens, but careful monitoring for Dutch elm disease is necessary to maintain the tree’s health.

text:
Natural history notes
The Common Buckeye (Junonia coenia) is characterized by their brown forewing that includes orange bars and a white band surrounding a large eyespot. The hindwing similarly has a large eyespot with an orange band near the edge. As the name suggests, Common Buckeyes are quite common and can be found year round. Some of their host plants include: Plantains (Plantago spp.), Florida Toadflax (Linaria floridana), and Frogfruit (Phyla nodiflora)

title: Pitted Stripeseed(Piriqueta cistoides)
text:
Natural history notes
The Pitted Stripeseed (Piriqueta cistoides) is a delicate wildflower of the southeastern United States and the Caribbean, thriving in sandy soils and open habitats. It produces bright yellow, five-petaled flowers that open for a single day, attracting bees and other pollinators. Its seeds have a distinctive pitted surface, giving the plant its common name. Though small and often overlooked, it contributes to the rich diversity of dry, coastal ecosystems.

title: Eastern Cottontail (Sylvilagus floridanus)
text:
Natural history notes
The Eastern Cottontail (Sylvilagus floridanus) is the most common rabbit in North America, easily recognized by the fluffy white underside of its tail. It thrives in fields, meadows, and brushy edges, where it feeds mainly on grasses, herbs, and garden plants. Highly prolific, females can produce several litters per year, each with multiple young. As a key prey species for hawks, foxes, coyotes, and other predators, it plays an essential role in many food webs.

title: Whitesnow (Drymaria cordata)
text:
Natural history notes
The Whitesnow (Drymaria cordata) is native to moist habitats in Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa, and has been introduced to many places in the tropics and subtropics, including the southeast US. It is known as one of the most aggressive weeds of the tropical and subtropical parts of the world. The North American distribution probably all adventive (not reported for the Southeastern US by Chapman 1883, Mohr 1901, or Small 1903). Its weed is weak-stemmed, breaking easily and effortlessly spreading to other areas. Seeds and fruit will stick to clothing, shoes, pets and other items from the yard.

title: Red Maple (Acer rubrum)
text:
Natural history notes
The Red Maple (Acer rubrum) is one of the most widespread and adaptable trees in eastern North America, thriving in wetlands, forests, and urban areas alike. It is named for its brilliant red features—buds in spring, flowers before leaf-out, and vibrant fall foliage. Its winged seeds, called samaras, are a key food source for squirrels, birds, and other wildlife. Because of its fast growth and tolerance for many soils, it is also a popular shade and ornamental tree.

title: Fourleaf Vetch (Vicia acutifolia)
text:
Natural history notes
The Fourleaf Vetch (Vicia acutifolia) is a slender, climbing or trailing annual legume native to the southeastern United States. It typically grows in open woods, roadsides, and fields, using tendrils at the tips of its compound leaves to climb on surrounding vegetation. Its leaves usually have 4–8 narrow leaflets, and the plant produces small purple to violet pea-like flowers, often singly or in pairs. Its genus name Vicia is Latin for vetch, a group of climbing legumes long recognized in agriculture and wild flora.

text:
Natural history notes
The cloudless sulphur (Phoebis sennae) is a vibrant yellow butterfly that is common throughout Florida. It occurs in a variety of habitats but tends to breed in disturbed, open areas. The eggs are laid white and gradually turn orange as they mature. Cloudless sulphurs migrate south for the winter, so they are most abundant in Florida during the fall, especially in open habitats. Their host plants are various species in the pea family.

IUCN: Least Concern; Florida: Not Listed
Rarity note: Tall, native, sharp grass found in the southeastern United States ## Natural history notes

Swamp sawgrass (Cladium mariscus) is a native sedge commonly found in freshwater and brackish-water systems throughout the southeastern United States. This wetland staple can be easily identified by its sharp serrations (“teeth”) on the undersides of the leaves, which can cut skin. This plant is especially pervasive in the Florida Everglades and is the grass referenced when describing the Everglades as a “River of Grass.” The species recently went through changes to its scientific name, so the species seen at DeLuca could potentially be Cladium jamaicense, which used to be a subspecies of Cladium mariscus.

title: Letourneux’s Jewel Cichlid (Rubricatochromis letourneuxi)
text:
Natural history notes
Letourneux’s Jewel Cichlid (Rubricatochromis letourneuxi) is a brightly colored freshwater fish native to rivers and lakes of northern Africa. It is known for its vibrant red body speckled with iridescent blue spots, which become even more striking during breeding season. This species is highly territorial, with pairs fiercely defending nests where eggs and fry are guarded by both parents. Though valued in the aquarium trade, it can become invasive outside its native range, competing with local fish for food and habitat.

The Fragrant Eryngo (Eryngium aromaticum) is a spiny, thistle-like wildflower native to the sandy soils of the southeastern United States. Despite its prickly appearance, it produces clusters of tiny, fragrant flowers that attract a wide range of pollinators, especially bees and butterflies. Its tough, drought-tolerant growth allows it to thrive in dry, open habitats where few other plants persist. As both a nectar source and a hardy ground cover, it supports pollinator diversity in fragile ecosystems.

title: Pink Sundew (Drosera capillaris)
text:
Natural history notes
The Pink Sundew (Drosera capillaris) is a small carnivorous plant found in nutrient-poor wetlands, bogs, and sandy soils across the southeastern United States. Its leaves are covered in sticky, glandular hairs that glisten in the sun and trap unsuspecting insects, which the plant digests to supplement its nutrient intake. Despite its delicate size, it plays an important role in balancing insect populations in its habitat. In spring, it produces tiny pink to white flowers that rise above the sticky leaves, ensuring pollinators don’t get caught in its traps.

title: Double-crested Cormorant (Nannopterum auritum)
text:
Natural history notes
The Double-crested Cormorant (Nannopterum auritum) is a widespread waterbird of North America, often seen diving for fish in lakes, rivers, and coastal waters. Unlike many aquatic birds, its feathers get wet, which helps it dive efficiently but requires it to perch with wings outstretched to dry. It nests in colonies, often in trees or on islands, where its guano can heavily impact local vegetation. Once persecuted as a competitor to fisheries, the species has rebounded strongly and is now a familiar sight across much of its range.

The Rough Hedgehyssop (Gratiola hispida) is a small, herbaceous annual or perennial, native to the southeastern United States. It typically inhabits wetland habitats such as pond margins, ditches, floodplain depressions, and wet savannas. The stems are hairy, and leaves are opposite, lanceolate, and toothed. Flowers are small, tubular, and white to pale yellow, usually produced singly in leaf axils during spring and summer.

title: Brown-belted Bumble Bee (Bombus griseocollis)
text:
Natural history notes
Brown-belted Bumble Bees (Bombus griseocollis) are characterized by their black wings, black head, short dense hairs on their thorax with a belt of brown hairs. The Queen is much larger than both the males and workers. Brown-belted Bumble Bees emerge early in the spring and cease activity early in the fall. Their food and hosts include numerous families of flowering plants.

title: Appressed Bog Clubmoss (Lycopodiella appressa)
text:
Natural history notes
The Appressed Bog Clubmoss (Lycopodiella appressa) is a primitive, fern-like plant native to bogs, wet pine savannas, and marshes of the southeastern United States. It spreads by creeping stems that root along the ground, forming dense mats in moist, acidic soils. Its upright, cone-bearing shoots release spores rather than seeds, reflecting its ancient lineage. By stabilizing soils and contributing to bog structure, it plays a quiet but vital role in wetland ecosystems.

title: Hemlock Witchgrass (Dichanthelium portoricense)
text:
Natural history notes
The Hemlock Witchgrass (Dichanthelium portoricense) ia a perennial grass inhabits sandy woods, low pinelands, savannas, coastal sand dunes, and moist habitats. The genus name Dichanthelium means “twice flowering”, referring to the dual growth / flowering phases that many species in this genus show. In Florida, it occurs in numerous conservation areas and is considered native and secure in South Florida. It is a highly variable species with numerous intergrading forms, some possibly resulting from hybridization with other widespread species in the same region, such as D. sphaerocarpon and D. commutatum.

title: American Oak Beauty (Phaeoura quernaria)
text:
Natural history notes
The American Oak Beauty (Phaeoura quernaria) is a large moth of eastern North America, well camouflaged with mottled brown and gray wings that resemble tree bark. It is most often found in oak woodlands, where its caterpillars feed on the leaves of oaks and related trees. Adults are nocturnal and attracted to lights, though their cryptic patterns make them nearly invisible during the day. By cycling nutrients through leaf consumption, its larvae play a role in forest food webs.

title: Swamp Shield-Fern (Cyclosorus interruptus)
text:
Natural history notes
The Swamp Shield-Fern (Cyclosorus interruptus) is a robust, moisture-loving fern native to wetlands, swamps, and marsh edges of the southeastern United States. It forms dense clumps of bright green fronds that can reach over a meter tall, providing shelter for small animals and amphibians. Reproducing by spores, it thrives in consistently wet, shaded environments. Its presence is often a good indicator of healthy, undisturbed wetland habitats.

The yellow-bellied sapsucker (Sphyrapicus varius) primarily inhabits forests and feeds on insects. It breeds across Canada and the northeastern United States, and winters in the southern United States and Mexico. In Florida, it is considered a winter visitor. The species gets its name from its habit of drilling holes in trees to feed on the leaking sap, which often contains trapped insects.

title: Cutleaf Evening Primrose (Oenothera laciniata)
text:
Natural history notes
The Cutleaf Evening Primrose (Oenothera laciniata) is a low, sprawling biennial or short-lived perennial in the evening primrose family (Onagraceae), native to eastern North America but now introduced in other regions worldwide. Its name Oenothera comes from Greek, often interpreted as “wine scent,” because some species’ roots were thought to smell like wine. Like many evening primroses, the flowers open in the evening or at dusk, catering to nocturnal pollinators like sphinx moths.

The Lilac Tasselflower (Emilia sonchifolia) is a small, weedy wildflower native to Asia but now naturalized throughout the southeastern United States. It produces slender stems topped with pink to purplish tassel-like flower heads that bloom nearly year-round in warm climates. Often found in lawns, roadsides, and disturbed soils, it provides nectar for small butterflies and bees. Though considered a weed in some areas, it adds color and pollinator value to open, sunny habitats.

title: Everglades Crayfish (Procambarus alleni)
text:
Natural history notes
Also called the Florida crayfish, the Everglades crayfish (Procambarus alleni) is a native crayfish found in freshwater systems in central and south Florida. These are endemic to Florida, which means that this species can only be found in this state! It is a popular prey item of a variety of wading birds and sportfish, including white ibises, little blue herons, and largemouth bass. It can have a striking blue color, which makes it popular in the aquarium trade.

text:
Natural history notes
The Narrowleaf Silkgrass (Pityopsis graminifolia) is a perennial wildflower native to the southeastern United States, often found in dry, sandy soils and pine flatwoods. It produces bright yellow, daisy-like flowers in late summer and fall that attract a variety of pollinators. Its narrow, grasslike leaves are covered with silvery hairs, giving the plant a distinctive sheen and helping it conserve moisture. As a hardy, drought-tolerant species, it contributes to the resilience of fire-maintained ecosystems.

text:
Natural history notes
The Carolina Water-Hyssop (Bacopa caroliniana) is a creeping aquatic plant native to wetlands, ponds, and ditches across the southeastern United States. It has thick, succulent leaves that emit a lemony scent when crushed and produces small, pale blue to lavender flowers. The plant provides shelter for aquatic invertebrates and helps stabilize muddy shorelines. Its tolerance for submersion and attractive foliage have also made it popular in aquariums and water gardens.

title: Herb-of-Grace (Bacopa monnieri)
text:
Natural history notes
The Herb-of-grace (Bacopa monnieri) is a creeping, mat-forming perennial that occurs naturally in coastal hammocks and swales, swamps, salt and freshwater marshes, and along river, stream and ditch edges. It attracts a variety of small pollinators, and is a larval host plant for the White peacock butterfly. It has a similar appearance as its cousin, Lemon bacopa (Bacopa caroliniana), and is found in similar habitats. To differentiate them, crush a leaf. If you smell lemon, you know you have Lemon bacopa. Herb-of-grace will not emit a scent.

title: Florida Toadflax (Linaria floridana)
text:
Natural history notes
The Florida Toadflax (Linaria floridana) is an herbaceous annual or biennial in the plantain family, native to the southeastern United States. It typically grows on dry, sandy soils in habitats such as sandhills, scrub, dunes, and open woodlands. One way to distinguish L. floridana from other Toadflaxes in Florida is that its pedicels are densely glandular-pubescent and are at least twice as long as the calyx, and its spur is shorter than the calyx. Linaria species often are cultivated and some become naturalized.

title: Slender Yellow Woodsorrel (Oxalis dillenii)
text:
Natural history notes
The Slender Yellow Woodsorrel (Oxalis dillenii) is a small, low-growing perennial (sometimes annual) herb in the wood-sorrel family (Oxalidaceae), native to eastern and central North America but now found widely in disturbed sites, lawns, gardens, and roadsides. Its bright yellow, five-petaled flowers bloom through spring and summer, often closing in the evening or on overcast days. Like other Oxalis, it exhibits ballistic seed dispersal — the seed capsules burst open and can fling seeds several feet. Its epithet dillenii honors German botanist Johann Jacob Dillenius (1684–1747).

The Grass-leaved Arrowhead (Sagittaria graminea) is an aquatic plant found in shallow ponds, marshes, and slow-moving streams across eastern North America. Its submerged parts offer shelter for aquatic invertebrates and small fish, making it an important component of wetland ecosystems.

The Myrtleleaf St. John’s Wort (Hypericum myrtifolium) is a shrub native to wetlands and moist flatwoods of the southeastern United States. It bears glossy, myrtle-like leaves and bright yellow flowers that bloom through the summer, attracting a wide range of pollinators. Its tolerance for periodic flooding makes it an important stabilizer of wetland soils. The plant’s dense growth and long flowering season add color and structure to swamp and marsh edges.

title: Wild Turkey (Meleagris gallopavo)
text:
Natural history notes
The Wild Turkey (Meleagris gallopavo) is a large, ground-dwelling bird native to North America, best known for its fan-shaped tail and gobbling calls. It forages on the forest floor for acorns, seeds, berries, and insects, often scratching through leaf litter in search of food. Males, called toms, put on elaborate displays in spring—strutting, fanning their tails, and puffing up feathers to attract hens. Once nearly extirpated due to overhunting and habitat loss, Wild Turkeys have made a remarkable recovery through conservation efforts and reintroductions.

title: Swamp Bay (Persea palustris)
text:
Natural history notes
Swamp Bay (Persea palustris) is an evergreen tree of the southeastern United States, typically growing in wetlands, swamps, and along stream edges. Its aromatic leaves resemble those of the related Redbay and are sometimes used as a spice substitute. The small, dark fruits are an important food source for birds and mammals, while the dense foliage offers year-round cover. Like other members of the laurel family, it is vulnerable to the invasive redbay ambrosia beetle, which spreads laurel wilt disease.

title: Swamp Bay (Persea palustris)

Natural history notes
Michaux’s snoutbean (Rhynchosia michauxii) is a small native plant found in drier conditions. A member of the legume (Fabaceae) family, this plant’s roots form relationships with soil bacteria to fix nitrogen from the atmosphere into the soil. By doing this, legumes aid in restoring soil health, as they replenish the amount of nitrogen available in the sediment for other plants to use.

title: Deerberry (Vaccinium stamineum)
text:
Natural history notes
The Florida Deerberry (Vaccinium stamineum) is a variety of Deerberry distinguished by its pedicels and twigs lacking stipitate glands, and smooth fruits. Its common name “Deerberry” comes from the fact that deer, as well as other mammals and many bird species, eat both the foliage and fruits. It is fire-adapted: it has woody rhizomes underground, so even when aboveground branches burn, the plant resprouts. It is buzz-pollinated by bees (i.e., pollinators vibrate their flight muscles to dislodge pollen from poricidal anthers), which is an interesting specialized pollination mode among the Vaccinium group.

title: Deerberry (Vaccinium stamineum)

The Common Bogbuttons (Paepalanthus anceps) is a distinctive wildflower of wet savannas, bogs, and pine flatwoods in the southeastern United States. Its presence often signals a healthy, intact bog ecosystem.

text:
Natural history notes
The Io Moth (Automeris io) is a large and striking species, with wings that may be yellow or brown. Its forewings feature bold eyespot patterns, which the moth flashes when threatened. These eyespots resemble the eyes of large predators and can startle birds and other potential threats. In Florida, the Io Moth is widely distributed and uses a variety of host plants, including Florida fishpoison tree, royal poinciana, hibiscus, Washington fan palm, nettletree, and red mangrove.

text:
Natural history notes
The Golden Polypody (Phlebodium aureum) is a large, epiphytic fern native to tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas, including the southeastern United States. It grows on tree trunks and branches, using them for support while absorbing moisture and nutrients from the air. Its blue-green, lobed fronds and golden-brown spore clusters on the underside give the species its name. By forming lush mats on trees, it helps retain humidity and provides habitat for small invertebrates.

The Slash Pine (Pinus elliottii) is a tall, fast-growing pine native to the southeastern United States, especially common in flatwoods, wetlands, and coastal plains. It has long, glossy needles and produces large cones that provide food for squirrels and birds. Well adapted to fire, it regenerates quickly in burned areas and forms part of the iconic longleaf–slash pine ecosystem. Its strong, resin-rich wood has long been valued for lumber, pulp, and turpentine production.

The American Mistletoe (Phoradendron leucarpum) is a species of mistletoe in the Viscaceae family which is native to the United States and Mexico. It is hemiparasitic, living in the branches of trees. It is used in North America as a surrogate for the similar European mistletoe Viscum album, in Christmas decoration and associated traditions, as well as in rituals by modern druids. It is commercially harvested and sold for those purposes. It is the state floral emblem for the state of Oklahoma.

title: Torpedo Grass (Panicum repens)
text:
Natural history notes
The Torpedo Grass (Panicum repens) is a perennial rhizomatous grass. It spreads primarily through creeping, sharply pointed rhizomes that can penetrate deep into soil and waterlogged sediments, forming dense monocultures in wetlands, ditches, and along lakeshores. It thrives under a wide range of conditions, tolerating drought, periodic flooding, salinity, and nutrient-poor soils. First introduced to the U.S. for forage and erosion control, it quickly became one of Florida’s worst invasive grasses, now covering tens of thousands of acres.

The Southern Live Oak (Quercus virginiana) is found throughout southeastern United States, often draped in Spanish moss and sprawling with massive, arching limbs. Unlike most oaks, it keeps its leathery leaves year-round, providing shade and shelter in coastal woodlands and urban landscapes. Its acorns are an important food source for birds, squirrels, and deer, supporting a wide range of wildlife. Historically, its dense, durable wood was prized for shipbuilding, including the hulls of early American naval vessels.

The White-edged Witchgrass (Dichanthelium tenue) is a perennial member of the grass family. It grows in moist to dry, sandy woods, savannahs, and disturbed sites. The genus name Dichanthelium means “twice-flowering,” referring to its dual blooming strategy.

The Coastalplain Chaffhead (Carphephorus corymbosus) is a perennial wildflower native to the sandy pinelands and flatwoods of the southeastern United States. Adapted to fire-maintained habitats, it thrives in open conditions created by periodic burns. Its striking blooms add both beauty and ecological value to pine-dominated landscapes.

title: Virginia Creeper (Parthenocissus quinquefolia)
text:
Natural history notes
Virginia Creeper (Parthenocissus quinquefolia) is a vigorous, climbing vine native to eastern North America, often seen covering trees, fences, and walls. It attaches with small adhesive pads, allowing it to scale surfaces without harming them structurally. In autumn, its leaves turn a brilliant red, and its dark blue berries provide food for birds and small mammals. While sometimes mistaken for poison ivy, it can be distinguished by its five leaflets instead of three.

text:
Natural history notes
The White Octoblepharum Moss (Octoblepharum albidum) is a distinctive tropical moss found in humid forests, where it often grows on tree trunks, logs, and shaded soil. It forms loose, pale green to whitish tufts that stand out against darker vegetation. Like other mosses, it lacks true roots, instead absorbing water and nutrients directly through its leaves, which makes it sensitive to moisture conditions. By helping retain humidity and providing microhabitats for tiny invertebrates, it contributes to the health of forest ecosystems.

title: Ballmoss (Tillandsia recurvata)
text:
Natural history notes
Ballmoss (Tillandsia recurvata) is a small, gray-green epiphyte in the bromeliad family, commonly found attached to tree branches, power lines, and fences across the southeastern United States. Despite appearances, it is not parasitic—it gathers moisture and nutrients from the air through its specialized leaves. It forms dense, spherical clumps that provide shelter for insects and small spiders. Ballmoss thrives in humid environments and is an important part of the natural epiphyte community in subtropical forests.

title: Colombian Waxweed (Cuphea carthagenensis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Colombian Waxweed (Cuphea carthagenensis) is a somewhat erect to sprawling herb (sometimes becoming weakly woody at the base) that often reaches about 30–60 cm in height, with many branches. The seed dispersal mechanism is rather unusual: a thickened “placenta” inside the fruit can elongate and force open the flower tube, ejecting seeds — somewhat like a little mechanical catapult. In its seed oil, it contains a very high proportion of lauric acid. It has a long history of use in traditional medicine: in South America it has been used as a diuretic, hypotensive, blood purifier, antiprotozoal, laxative, etc.

text:
Natural history notes
The Southern Wiregrass (Aristida beyrichiana) is a keystone grass species of the longleaf pine ecosystems in the southeastern United States. It forms dense clumps of fine, needle-like leaves that fuel and recover quickly from periodic fires. Its flowering spikes appear in late summer, releasing seeds that provide food for birds and small mammals. By carrying fire and stabilizing sandy soils, it plays an essential role in maintaining the biodiversity of pine savannas.

title: Castor Bean (Ricinus communis)
text:
Natural history notes
The Castor Bean (Ricinus communis) is a fast-growing perennial shrub or small tree in the spurge family (Euphorbiaceae), native to Africa but now naturalized in warm regions worldwide. It can reach 2–5 m tall, with large, star-shaped leaves that are glossy and deeply lobed, giving it a tropical appearance. It produces spiny seed capsules containing mottled seeds that yield castor oil, used in medicine, cosmetics, and industry. Despite this utility, the seeds also contain ricin, a highly toxic protein. Ricin is so potent that just a few chewed seeds can be lethal, yet the purified oil is safe because ricin is water-soluble and not carried into the oil.

title: Sandhill Pinweed (Lechea torreyi)
text:
Natural history notes
The Sandhill Pinweed (Lechea torreyi) is a species of perennial flowering plant native to the U.S. southeast coastal plain. It occurs in sandy, fire-dependent pine habitats of the southeast including pine flatwoods, longleaf pine sandhill, and pine barrens. The genus name Lechea honors Johan Leche (1704–1764), a Swedish botanist and meteorologist. It has two recognized varieties: var. torreyi and var. congesta, differing in how tightly the floral panicles are clustered and the coloration of inner sepals in fruit.

title: White Lobelia (Lobelia paludosa)
text:
Natural history notes
The White Lobelia (Lobelia paludosa) is a perennial wetland wildflower. It typically grows in wet pine flatwoods, savannas, ditches, swamp edges, and dune swales. In Florida, it is considered endemic (or nearly so) and is assigned the wetland indicator status OBL (obligate wetland species) in the Atlantic & Gulf Coastal Plain region, meaning it almost always occurs in wetlands. The species epithet paludosa comes from Latin paludosus, meaning “boggy” or “swampy,” reflecting the plant’s preference for wet habitats.

title: Eastern Mosquitofish (Gambusia holbrooki)
text:
Natural history notes
Eastern Mosquitofish (Gambusia holbrooki) are characterized by their silver to forest green coloring on their top and sides with their sclaes outlined. They additionally have an upturned mouth and a rounded tail fin. Melanistic males are also possible and can been seen with large black spotting throughout its body and fins. Eastern Mosquitofish are hardy fish as they can tolerate variation in the temperature, salinty, and dissolved oxygen in the water. They feed on insects, such as mosquito larvae, along with crustaceans and plants. Like most mosquitofish, Eastern Mosquitofish will give birth to 40-60 live offspring.

title: Broad-leaved Goldenaster (Pityopsis latifolia)
text:
Natural history notes
The Broad-leaved Goldenaster (Pityopsis latifolia) is a rhizomatous perennial herb in the aster family. This taxon has a tangled taxonomic history: it has been placed in genera like Chrysopsis, Heterotheca, and has been considered a variety of Pityopsis graminifolia. More recent treatments have elevated a narrowly defined Pityopsis latifolia as a Florida endemic, restricting its circumscription. It is adapted to fire-managed ecosystems: regular, low-intensity burns favor it by reducing competition from woody plants and encouraging flowering and resource allocation to belowground parts.

title: Tropical Soda-Apple (Solanum viarum)
text:
Natural history notes
The Tropical Soda-Apple (Solanum viarum) is an invasive shrub native to South America that has spread widely across the southeastern United States. It forms dense, thorny thickets that crowd out native vegetation and reduce pasture quality. The plant produces round, mottled green-and-white fruits resembling tiny watermelons, which are eaten by wildlife and livestock, aiding seed dispersal. Because of its rapid growth and persistence, it is considered a serious agricultural and ecological pest.

title: Perennial Goobergrass (Amphicarpum muehlenbergianum)
text:
Natural history notes
The Perennial Goobergrass (Amphicarpum muehlenbergianum) is a warm-season grass native to the sandy pinelands and moist flatwoods of the southeastern United States. It’s unique for producing two types of flowers—one above ground and one hidden underground—that both form seeds, an adaptation to variable environments. Its dense, fibrous roots help stabilize soil and support fire-adapted ecosystems. By providing cover and food for insects and small animals, it contributes to the health of pine savannas.
